I can only give five stars to this place for the experience we got and the price we got it at.

Found this place on Yelp alone...I came in 10 minutes before the kitchen closed in the middle of the NBA championship game and still managed to get amazing service and fantastic food.

Service - 5 stars
Drinks - 5 stars
Mussels - 4.5 stars (it's a tomato based sauce)
Fries - 4 stars
Tat tar - 5 stars - but have your sever mix it

The vibe is great and the building is gorgeous, wonderful place to grab a full meal or a late night(ish) snack.

Great service. Great food. Great ambience. If you're looking for a quiet place with the family - don't go here. If you're looking to grab drinks and eat great food with friends this is your spot. Fish and chips hit the spot. Brussels sprouts are excellent. Enjoy!

We walked in on a ridiculously beautiful and sunny breezy Sunday during Lollapalooza last weekend.  The house was a' buzzin' with all sorts of guests due to Lollapalooza taking over the streets one scantily clad teenager at a time (kids these days...).  

Anywhooo, we were seated right away surprisingly due to the crowds.  The eclectic array of guests seated closely together made for a lively and friendly experience, tourists and committed Lollapaloozers alike.  We were also able to scope out everyone's food like any good yelper would do.  

We had quite the assortment of goodies: scones, scotch egg and mussels and it was perfect.  

Scotch egg -- so, how can these ever not be good? Hardboiled egg, sausage, seemingly bland (as it would be fried) but with mustard.  

Orange Current Scones -- perfectly flavored, strong but not overpowering, and a lil' sweet.   Wait, was that the scones or my date? Two homemade jams.  Can't quite articulate the jam flavors (let's say fruit) but I don't think it'll stop you.  Easily one of the best scones I've ever had.  

PEI Mussels -- now these were interesting!  Mussels are great for a lot of reasons and these were anything but ordinary.  Vindaloo curry made this really outstanding -- not overpowering heat but enough fire and flavor to make it decadent.  

The space overall is spacious and beautiful and there is a sweet patio too!

My husband & I came here for our anniversary brunch. We had nothing but excellent service. Our waiter Paul was very attentive and friendly. The food was unique and flavorful! We loved the great music and the atmosphere. We will highly recommend the Gage!

You know that Meg Ryan scene in the restaurant, from When Harry Met Sally?  Me neither.  I never saw the movie.  But me, eating the lamb shank from The Gage was what I'd imagine that scene was like.  Oh.  My.  Gage.  It was the most perfectly cooked piece of meat.  Big and tender...like a girl likes it (at least that's what your mom said).  The sides were exquisite, the wine was divine and the service was on point.  Did not disappoint!

This place rocked, hands down! It was right over by The Bean or more formally known as Cloud Gate, and for my first visit to Chi-town I had to check it out, glad I did. Stellar menu, great drinks, cool ice cubes, good looking crowd, amazing location, awesome interior, stupendous lobster roll (as said by David S. - light and fresh!)

I'm ready to visit Chicago in the summer, everyone talks about the city in the summer as the best time you can imagine, well I plan on visiting again when it's a bit warmer, and I'll be posting up at The Gage without a doubt.

-Eric Statzer

Was a little surprised at the service and food considering the reviews this place has on yelp. I came in to the restaurant and as per my custom, I immediately asked the server what were the notables on the menu. I do that so I can insure I try the best of that restaurant. I was told the Trout as well as the venison were pretty good. We got the mussels as well. The mussels came with a vindaloo curry that was mediocre at best. I've had better curry mussels for a much cheaper price (was $18). The main course came next. It's rare that I say this about most plates at restaurants, but the trout was under seasoned and worst of all, completely bland and devoid of any flavor. There were too many things going on with the dish and none of it helped make the dish anything more than meh! And for $28 I find that unacceptable. The venison burger by contrast was actually pretty good and def worth getting. Although still too expensive at $19, it was not regrettable. Unfortunately the food was not the only complaint.
Our server made some questionable remarks like "the fish and chips are low brow compared to the trout" (huh? How does that help me determine what tastes better?!) And worst of all, through the entire meal, he never bothered to come over and ask us how the food was?! If he had I would have told him early on how the trout was sub par, but since he didn't come till the end to drop off the bill, I had to tell him at the end. He did do a last minute hail mary by taking the trout off the bill, but by that point I had a totally forgettable experience and wanted to get out there ASAP.
The 3 stars are for the ambiance of the restaurant, the venison burger and the server's attempt at salvaging the experience.

A girlfriend insisted that I couldn't leave Chicago without coming here. She claimed it's in her top 5 all time favorite and most memorable meals. She made me promise I would get the Scotch egg and the venison carpaccio. One of two isn't bad. They didn't have the venison carpaccio on the menu, but they did have a venison burger - holy mother of gawd....this has to be one of the best burgers I've ever had. True story. It was so full of flavor, perfectly cooked and just well, insane. The crispy fries that came with it were just as perfect. Paired with an Oregon pinot, it was blissful.

My bf is obsessed with all things french, so we started with the house poutine with smoked wild boar ragoût, pickled red onion and cheese curds. omg...so amazing...so rich...and so my new last meal on earth. Stupid-good!
We also had a side of brussell sprouts with pork belly. Usually I prefer my sprouts roasted and crispy, but these were soft and most likely blanched and sauteed. I still loved them. Oh, and the scotch egg. I had never had one, but it's been on my to-try list. Super delicious! Paired with greens and a simple dollop on yellow mustard.

Killer wine and beer list, excellent service by a the cutest waiter with a darling mid-western accent and an all around great vibe. It was packed at 2:00 for lunch on a random Thursday and I can see why. Love. Love. Love.

The Gage was so special, we went there twice in one weekend! Once for brunch and once for late night cocktails. The design of the restaurant is very beautiful, with an amazing focal bar! Bartenders were extremely nice and welcoming. Food was excellent, we split the eggs benedict and cinnamon roll, and I had a salty dog and a coffee. The presentation was on point, especially the plates, flatware, and coffee set up! We returned that same night after dinner to have a night cap. We sat at a very romantic candle light table across from the bar. I had a black manhattan, which I ended up switching for a regular manhattan because it was too bitter for me (my fault entirely). The manhattan was perfect and the atmosphere was gorgeous! We will be back the next time we are in Chicago and will suggest to any friends staying in the area!
Enjoyed brunch with friends at The Gage, great spot, good food, nice ambiance.   Wish we had a spot like this in Silicon Valley.

pics.caption: Go Ireland!!   Beat all blacks in nov 5th

review.des:
Nice but expensive at a point that its overpriced. US$ 12 dollars for an Irish Coffee? WTF
I had an Irish coffee and a tuna tarter and that cost me 40 dollars. Most of the good food on the menu as marked as MP (Market Price). Tuna tartar was "good" but not excellent so I think 3 stars is reasonable. Cheers

The Gage is one of the popular-rated restaurants on Yelp, so we put this as one of our top choices to try. We were offered to wait for the main dining room or eat first-come-first-serve in the bar area. We chose to sit at a tiny table near the door. The place is upscale, waitstaff all in formal attire, and a very small menu.

We ordered the striped bass with a saffron butter sauce with a bed of vegetables and a bets hire pork with white beans and bacon medley. Both were very delicious. The portions though did not fill us up. My husband's pork had two massive bones, which we felt was a little false advertising once he separated meat from bone. Just the two dinners without tip was $70.

It was a nice restaurant, but we went somewhere else for dessert. I know this is Chicago, but we felt it was a bit pricey for not a lot of food. No bread, soup, or salad.

pics.caption: Large bones made up 1/3 of the Berkshire pork

review.des:
Saturday afternoon for lunch, first time here very packed great ambience if you can get seated in the bar area. Drink/craft beer list was just okay nothing special.

Waiter was on point, high level of detail however slightly over barring when I told him I wanted to take the rest of my burger (which was really solid) home with me. He told me to finish it there I said box it, he never brought it back in a box. That is mainly why I can't give it a 5 star.

We came here post museum for a late lunch. Really great atmosphere. Good masculine pub with an upscale feel.

My fish and chips came in a nice présentation. Well cooked, very crispy but the meat itself could have used more seasoning.

The gage venison burger was the bomb. Never had such a tender burger. Cooked with Woodland muschroom, smoked gouda, fried Jalapeño, picked onions. Simply delicious.

Downside: the service felt rushed. You get a sense that all the waiters are thinking about the next people they have to serve. Must be the high turnover.

Overall great lunch option if you are in that area.
Still outstanding in terms of food and service.  The lobster roll was divine, chips with curry sauce addictive.

pics.caption: Wood roasted mushroom sandwich and fries

review.des:
Nice location by grant park. A little pricy due to loop proximity but good for a business lunch. Enjoyed the Amish chicken, although not sure am the Amish prepare chicken like that!  

Drinks looked nice, as did the scotch egg. There were tons of menu items I would have ordered.

Waiters were attentive and the place filled up very quickly at lunch time.

Packed house for lunch on a typical weekday in Chicago. Patio is first come first serve and even that was almost completely filled when we stumbled in as tourists. Let's cut to the chase since it's only 3 stars for me.

The food is alright. I had a sandwich and soup lunch combo for $12 which included the smoked salmon sandwich which was pretty delicious. 4 out of 5 tables around me got this exactly full sandwich without the soup. The house fried chips that comes with it were awesome. However, the fennel scallop soup was only a creamy let down. My girlfriend had the fish and chips lunch platter and it was literally 3 huge chunks of fresh fish in light batter. You definitely get lots of fish but ours lacked flavor. Quite bland actually and sauce was lackluster.

They do have an impressive bar with half liter mugs of Oktoberfest beer specials and the ambiance is bustling with the business crowd. Again, it's an OK place for lunch.

pics.caption: Smoked Salmon sandwich with Scallops & Fennel soup

review.des: We visited Chicago from Cleveland- and this is one of Chicago's eminent restaurants. The Black Manhattan was made by the bartender with perfection- the Scotch Egg is an excellent first course, their mushroom soup special sated our palates - had just the right amount of cream- and complemented their game meat menu. I went next for the Fried Quail salad, which was tangy and had crisp and creamy slaw. The venison burger was our final selection- and a signature dish it is- it was a complete party in our mouth of flavor. I wish I could remember our servers name- she wore glasses- and served us at a table in the back of the restaurant across from the cook's line- because it was the best service I ever had- so knowledgeable, attentive, and pleasant. This restaurant is pure perfection.

While the server tried to steer me toward a pricier steak entree,  I ordered the fish and chips on recommendation.   Glad I did!  One of the best I've ever had!  Brussel sprouts were a huge hit as well.

pics.caption: Fish and chips with Brussel sprouts on the side.

review.des: One of the best breakfast places we've visited in the Chicago area!  The food was superb and our server, Gabby, was very helpful in assisting to navigate the drinks and brunch menu. A nice twist to eggs Benedict, I had poached eggs over their house-made sausage, tomato slices and English muffin topped with a killer poblano hollandaise sauce. Their breakfast special of sirloin with poached eggs on a bed of fresh veggies topped with hollandaise was excellent!  The staff here are friendly, fast to act, and attentive to the customers.

On the recommendation of a colleague, he and I stopped by to give this place a shot. He met the owners just the night before at their other restaurant next door.

The place was packed at 6PM, but we didn't wait long. Sat at the bar for a Moscow Mule. It was stronger, but REALLY good.

When I finally sat and preserved dinner, I decided on the Bone-in Filet. Supposedly, his is a VERY rare cut only served at a handful of restaurants.

When I received the steak, I thought it looked nothing liked the picture. I like my steaks medium rare and ordered as such. It was really good, but not sure if it worth $60. Maybe a great $45 steak. Sauces provided were not over-powering and went well with the meat. The greens were decent but complimented the steak. You pay extra for the sides so get ready to spend a pretty dime.

All in all, I liked the food. A bit pricey for what you get.

Came in the night after Lollapalooza & surprisingly got seated right away. The prices are kinda ridiculous, but I thought it was worth it.

Ambiance: dark, low lighting, semi-loud
Service: great, checked back frequently & answered questions, water & alcoholic beverages were always full
Food: was exceptional

Burrata was to die for.  Firm & melts in your mouth. Simple dish- cheese & bread. That's it.

We were not very impressed with The Gage.  We stopped in for lunch after visiting the Art Institute.  We were seated right away and quickly noticed there was a very cold draft hitting our table.  They serve brunch until 4pm on the weekends.  We each ordered a sandwich and opted for a side salad over fries.  Our sandwiches arrive and mine was not the correct one.  We sat waiting for someone to come to the table to check in so we could tell them I received the wrong meal.  I was told the correct sandwich would arrive right away.  I think I sat for around ten minutes waiting as I awkwardly picked at the salad that came with the incorrect sandwich.  When the correct sandwich did arrive at the table, I could hardly eat it because it was so greasy and messy.  I did enjoy the salad though.  I'm not in a hurry to return.

We were here for late night cocktails and the bar area is nice for that. Lots of high tables and seating right at bar side. We had two drinks off their special menu a Pisco Punch something like a blueberry whiskey smash, plus a Guinness. All great. We were west coast folks and timed it right to see the Warriors win game 5 on one of the bar TVs.

Loved the look and feel of this place! Old school bar vibe with an up to date yummy menu. Not a huge menu but lots of great options! Loved the friend pickles. Service was great, well versed in the menu and attentive. Great place to bring guests or have drinks with friends if you're going for a classier, bit pricier vibe.

Great drinks and food!! We had there ahi tuna and it was amazing great flavors, we also had there devilish egg and that was something different I've never had but was really good and there fries with the curry gravy my friend was in love with. I'm not big on curry but I did enjoy the gravy!!!
Lovely! Thank you to the great service, they were extremely attentive, kind, and gave us great recommendations for dessert. The environment is warm and cozy and the atmosphere makes for a great time.

Probably the best Old-Fashioned I've ever had in Chicago.  I think it's the in-house made sherry-syrup that makes it special, smooth and delicate.  I really wished I've taken the uber out to the city because I really wanted another one.  Who am I kidding, I would probably drink that until they cut me off and kick me out of the restaurant.

Ordered Scotch egg which were damn delicious, and Tuna tartare which was also great.  I had the venison burger (med-rare) and my lovely date had the sea food mix grill with extra scallop which looked damn good.  Except the fact that they drizzle fresno chili oil on top and she was little surprised but nevertheless, both of our plates were clean.  

As we were looking at the dessert menu (didn't get any) the table next to us ordered the house made sausage and let me tell you, that looked really good.  Definitely ordering that next time.  A definite 5 stars, I would just come back here for the Old-Fashioned but food was also impressive.

Location: Across the spitting fountains
Excellent:
Pre-theater meal
Private party function space
Quick meal at the bar
Service and beers on Tap
Great first date place

Summary: Gastropub with a friendly vibe which is perfect for a first date or pre-theater crowd before a show by the loop.

Casual or dressy, this place had great food which was diverse and unexpectedly not your typical bar food joint. Great cheeses and savory savory dishes. It's a place you may come for happy hour, but transition into a nice dinner.

I was able to walk to the B of A theater a few blocks away in the loop.
Cool,  lively atmosphere, food was fast, waiter was nice. Close to Millennium Park and Art Institute of Chicago.  Nothing outstanding about this place but it was good. Had a burger and a salad

pics.caption: Get ready to enGAGE! Bills are reasonably priced.

review.des: I've been wanting to try this place out and I finally did. Went with the cowboy ribeye and boy it was good. One of the best steaks I've ever had.

For years I've been trying to come to the Gage and finally I'm here. I was not disappointed, not one bit. First, I like the crowd; mostly were business personnel there for their lunch break, couples, and a few college students. We came for restaurant week and ordered each option on the menu. The short rib croquettes were delicious and quite filling, and the tomato bisque was light and creamy. I love the lobster salad and the lamb tikka entrée was hearty and spicy. Finally, the chocolate truffle cake was rich and just the right amount. It's been a long time since we've had a really good chocolate truffle dessert. The service was very friendly and very attentive. Loved my experience at the Gage!

Cool atmosphere. Good food. We were a little sticker shocked on the price of the bison steak special when the bill arrived (no price mentioned before). Service was timely and attentive but not particularly friendly or warm. Amish chicken was great. Mashed potatoes underwhelming, Bison steak was very good. Recommend requesting a booth instead of a table.

I came here for no particular reason - just wanted to treat myself to a nice meal and stumbled across the Gage. I wasn't too hungry for some reason, so probably didn't enjoy the meal as much as I could have. We tried:

1. House poutine: meh. I feel like poutine isn't meant to be high end, and something about this poutine was off - the flavors were too "gentle" (for lack of a better word) and it was WAY too oily.

2. Seared Sea Scallops with Korean "BBQ" Short Rib and kimchi: interesting spin on the dish. Scallops are one of my all time favorite foods, and I ALWAYS get them whenever they're on the menu (read: I've tried too many scallop dishes for my own good over the past several years). This was a unique preparation - the "korean bbq" (I'm korean and no, this was not anything like LA galbi) was still flavorful and the kimchi added a nice flavor profile as well. The scallops had a beautiful sear and came out medium rare.

3. Fish and chips: I tried my friend's order, and it was great. The flavors of the fish really came through, which is rare since it's battered and fried. I also liked the presentation of the fish (came out in "newspaper" wrapping).

The complimentary bread starter and the Riesling I ordered were both great as well. Service was attentive but not intrusive.

The Gage isn't particularly creative with their menu, but for what it is, food definitely of quality. Solid 4 stars.

Conveniently located on accessible Michigan Avenue, The Gage offers top quality food but at an elevated price tag.

The Gage is a trendy spot where business casual is the dominant attire. The mood is casual but with a touch of elegance. A restaurant that seems more geared towards a business dinner than a romantic setup.

Food is pretty good, no complains at all! We started our dinner with a burrata, which had an original twist and was very nice, and a salmon-quinoa salad, which the salmon tasted great but the overall dish was a bit dry.

I followed with the catch of the day: a white fish over bok choi and topped with an apple salad. Very good taste and portion size was very reasonable. I'd definitely recommend this.

We finished our meal with a fantastic dessert: chocolate crème brûlée! I had never tried such a combination but GREAT IDEA! We absolutely loved it and completely devoured it! Portion is pretty generous, good for sharing.

Overall, the place is very good but expensive (we ended up paying $75 per head with no wine). For this price tag, there are other places I'd revisit before coming back here.

pics.caption: Catch of the day over bok choi, topped with Apple salad

review.des:
Stopped by for drinks and appetizers after work today. Wasn't very crowded.
Appetizers were good. Service was stuffy. There are better places to go.
Food was pricey but good enough for us to come back.
Verrrry tasty..love the outdoor area across from melinium park..pork chop juice ...key Lime pie light. Didn't have any apt.s but looked yummy..will come again
Delicious food and the wait staff is fantastic. We had a super quick lunch and really enjoyed the place. Worth a stop.

Dinner at The Gage last night - and it was fantastic !
Food, service, atmosphere was incredible.  Benjamin our waiter was great, very helpful and had a thorough understanding of the menu.  
Price wise good value for the quality that you get.
Why can't we find restaurants like this in Naples, FL ?....
Can't wait to get back to Chicago again - and will certainly re visit The Gage

This is a cute place on Michigan. i went on St Patrick's day and they had fiddlers. While this is a cute idea it made for an extremely loud evening. I'm not sure if they have live music often, but it might be better to check out the place when they don't. i will say the food is FANTASTIC. We had fried pickles to start and they are probably the best I've ever had. Then also god lamb. It was melt in your mouth good. The bathrooms were a level down and it looked like they had a cute little private room that would be really great for a private event/party. Looked like it would hold about 30ish people for a happy hour. I would come back here

Walked by many times and always heard good things about it but finally made it there. Generally speaking you should make a reservation here because most of the times I've walked by it's been crowded. It's a little pretentious here but I assure you, you can be casually dressed here.

Went for a work dinner and all of our food was fantastic. We started with the tuna tartare, the burrata, and poutine. Yum! Everything was so fresh. Our entrees were all fantastic, it was hard to decide what to get. Usually I'm a picky eater, but there were plenty of options for everyone on this menu. I ultimately opted for the lamb chops special which was great. They do change up their menu frequently.

It can get a bit loud at times, but I think it's still a good date place. All of our service was great, but I will say the server who brought our wine, not sure if he was a sommelier or not but he wasn't our main server, was quite curt. It was a really turn off for what was a very lovely meal.

Other than that, I will come back.

We lived in  Chicago for a little over 2 years and came here like more than 10 times by now. This is our favorite place, their food is so good especially their burger and the vandelo mussel. I keeps on telling friend this is a must try place in Chicago, so do you!
Fantastic! Great service, friendly and professional. The food was soooo delicious and served quickly and hot! Guinness was fabulous ;)

pics.caption: Scallops with octopus, and I substituted buttermilk mashed potatoes! To die for!

review.des: While on vacation in Chicago, the girls and I decided to stop in for a cocktail. They have a neat option called dealers choice that allows you to select your preferred spirit, glass type and flavor profile. Then the mixologist creates a signature drink for you. We enjoyed the drinks and ambiance.

I had amazing time here! We were looking for lunch during a long break at Chicago. I saw reviews of this restaurant and noticing that it is probably expensive but wanted a treat. So went there and checked the menus which wasn't that pricey. There was some wait time so we sat at the bar. The barman was amazing: we wanted to share a burger and have some extra sides. When food arrived we got two half burgers in separate plates with all the sides. What a service. Fast, thoughtful and food was amazing. Highly recommended

We didn't eat anything but stopped in for a cocktail on a Saturday around 5:15. The place was packed! Fun atmosphere, service was pretty good and my water was constantly full. The martini I got was decent not amazing but certainly drinkable! I'd love to come back and try the food!

Highly suggested!

Visiting Chicago with my family on Saturday March , 19th. We had 11 people in our party around 1:30pm. The host staff was very friendly upon us walking up and asking for all 11 to sit. The restaurant was full and busy. Bartenders were very helpful and patient as we ordered a drink for the wait.

Got sat around 20-30 minutes later. Our server and other staff were fantastic!  Food exceeded our expectations. Very high quality food and service, great presentations, and professional follow up by managers.

Cannot say enough good things about this experience.

This place is one of the most amazing places to eat and enjoy in Chicago!

Since this original review we've eaten here almost every time we are in Chicago for brunch lunch or dinner and it is CONSISTENTLY fantastic!

pics.caption: Had an awesome brunch at The Gage as usual! The Scottish Egg was wonderful!

review.des: Amazing Poutine! I would highly recommend this after a few hours of walking thru the art institute.  Have lunch and maybe a drink or 2,  then head back to the institute of art for more displays :)  Excellent service and great "dirty" martinis!
Great food and great service. Clearly management cares about delivering a fabulous experience, and they came by our table checking in. Wonderful!

Showed up one morning for brunch. Had a tomato soup, which was good but a little saltier than it should have been.  My friend recommended the Gage Venison Burger, but I was a fool and got the lobster roll, which was underwhelming. There was nothing particularly wrong with it, it just wasn't very good, strictly speaking. The roll wasn't cut open enough, so it was difficult to eat, like a half-filled sandwich. It was accompanied by kettle cooked chips on the side, which I didn't bother with. (I don't think that was an appropriate side.)

The atmosphere was fine. I think my opinion of this place could be significantly higher (i.e. I might give four stars) if I had gotten one of the burgers instead.
The cocktails here are way overrated and weak, a $14/cocktail should not be watered down! The food was halfway decent, however. I guess people love the location...? For me: it was just meh.

Loved the watercress mushroom sandwich. Fancy and filling ~ the perfect duo.

The restaurant is perfect for semi-casual or fancy brunch and lunch. The presentation of the food is beautiful and simple. I am sure the dinner atmosphere and menu offers more fanciness and deliciousness as well.

The servers are excellent and so polite and helpful. Several waiters came to make sure our waters were always filled and the coffee warm.

pics.caption: Fish and chips. Fish is caressed in newspaper. How chic!

review.des: It was a delicious dinner. Servers were great and we didn't have to wait to be seated. (Monday night 6:30pm) I got Passion fruit soda as the server recommended. I was satisfied with it! My colleagues got beer and whiskey, they were happy too! Tartar and grilled pepper was also good. Main menu portions are not big just keep in mind. But the quality of food is very high. My halibut was cooked just right that it was moist and amazing texture. As for dessert, banana pie was quite heavy none of us finished it. One person who got berry cheese cake was very happy with his dessert tho. Overall I recommend this place! Will be back when I come back to Chicago next time!

pics.caption: Banana pie! Delicious but heavy. Too much topping and thick graham crackers.

review.des:
Wes the waiter made our time here special. He answered questions about the options with encyclopedic knowledge! The salmon special that we had was superb and enhanced by the Brussels sprout side- they were delicious!
Grant ambience and location near our hotel was another plus. Don't miss this one while in Chicago.

Overall is mediocre. When you pay $50 per person for dinner, you are expecting excellent service and food.

Food was good, but nothing wows us. We ordered the poutine, duck and market fish. Poutine was good and actually pretty large portion. Duck was good but nothing surprised, I wished it could have more kick in the flavor. The market fish for today was reckfish which i never had it before. The texture of the fish was smooth, my boyfriend enjoyed it.

Service was okay. No eye contact, no conversation and no explanation for the menu. I did find the service uneven here. I overheard the next table when they asked about the market fish. Their waiter was very friendly and knowledgeable. Compared to our table, when I asked the same question earlier, our waiter answered "reckfish!" lol

We had reservations; so, our party of five did not wait for a table on a busy Thursday evening!  This is a quaint gastro-pub directly across the street from Millennium Park.. exceedingly busy with foot traffic! Accordingly, it is a very loud venue! Our wait staff were quite good! Our food was excellent from the salads to scallops to the enormous pork chop one diner ordered! Would not hesitate to return anytime we find ourselves in Chicago!

My sister in law and myself are visiting from California, and we had a wonderful dining experiences at gage .  We ordered Sangiovese and There farmers markets salad so fresh and just delicately made and for our entrée we ordered fish special and it was so Delicious. But most of all is there crémé brûle that just made our girls night more fun. I absolutely recommend this restaurant to out of town visitors.
P.S We shared our meal and it was perfect!

pics.caption: The crème brûlé to die for!

review.des:
I've been here twice: once for drinks and dessert and once for Sunday lunch. They were both great experiences. I made last-minute reservations for the brunch and I did not make reservations for drinks/dessert (because it was 7:45 on a weeknight). Both were great experiences! I'll share a little about each.

Sunday lunch: I had just completed the Chicago triathlon and suffice it to say that I was very hungry. Energy bars and a banana were just not doing it for me. I needed real sustenance! Three of us arrived at The Gage and we were seated right away. The service was seriously on point. Everyone went out of their way to take care of us and treated is with the utmost respect even though I was wearing a triathlon tshirt and I had a huge black racing number tattoo going down the side of one arm with a black sharpie marker wave number on the other. Our waiter was actually interested in what I had competed in and asked me about it. I ordered a mushroom sandwich with fries. It was really delicious. The fries were so good that when a homeless person saw me walking outside with the leftovers and asked me for them, I said no because they were so good that I needed to covet them. My friend didn't like her cold soup (it was supposed to be prepared as such), so our lovely server brought her out a new bowl of something different. He also left the cold soup in case someone else wanted to eat it, which was cool. This was an awesome experience!

Weekday drinks/dessert: There weren't many seats available without a reservation, which surprised me because it was almost 8 PM on a weeknight, but they seated us at a table near the door and brought another chair. The three of us each ordered a drink. I went with the hot cider because it was cold outside. My drink was good, but my friend's hot Irish coffee was better. Our service was really great the whole meal. We had trouble flagging down our server at one point and the hostess graciously came over and bright my friend's old fashioned to the bar because it was too strong for her. Once the bartender added some sprite, she said it was much better. Our dessert (pot de creme) was good, but I wasn't blown away. It couldn't compare to the pot de creme from Autre Monde (this is my official plug for it if you haven't been there). The candied cashews didn't seem to gel with the dish. Also, the serving size was pretty small and a little pricey. Of course, this is all to be expected at a "$$$" establishment.

Overall, I had two great experiences here. I'm a bit torn between 4 and 5 stars. The service is really incredible, but some of the food is a little off. I expect to be back here many more times in the future, especially because I still haven't had the pleasure of trying their fish and chips (or their red snapper). I hope I'll be able to update this review to five stars when the time comes.

We came to The Gage for Easter brunch. When you advertise an Easter brunch, I think it's assumed that there will be multiple offerings for the breakfast side of the brunch. I ordered the Benedict which I did enjoy but it had an interesting green hollandaise and by interesting, I mean borderline weird. The Gage potatoes were delicious.  I was hoping for a great Easter experience but was a bit disappointed. Maybe their regular dinner menu might be more to my liking.
Love the fried pickles to start however, the Duck was amazing.  Perfectly cooked.  My Friend had the halibut which had so many fabulous favors.

Conveniently located across the street from the Institute of Art (this is totally worth noting), The Gage is good, real good. I had the Jambalaya and it was perfect - right spice, right heat, right temperature, right (you get it).

The bar was inviting but so are the booths. The bathroom is downstairs and if you visit its like walking into the 1940s - with small ceramic tiles and lots of wood.

Such a cool vibe in here.

Excellent service.  

I had the caesar salad and the middle eastern lamb shank. I also tried the chips with curry sauce.  All were excellent. If I had any criticism, it would be that the lamb was very slightly over salted. I am sensitive to that!  

Bar area - which I was offered as a lone diner - was crowded and noisy. But I was also offered a large booth for my sole use, which was much more pleasant

Recommended.

I was excited to return here with my daughter. For a holiday we were seated promptly and it was busy. We both had the cheeseburgers which were so juicy and tender. The service was very attentive. The burgers came with fries and we were asked about the gravy. It's a curry sauce but I had it on the side. This didn't wow me but perhaps it's a culture thing. Anyway, it was a lovely afternoon with delicious food.

Unique menu, food was delicious and had they had a very good beer and wine selection with interesting cocktails. Two of our party had fish and chips which was delicious and presented very nicely on a wood plank. Ahi tuna/tomato salad was wonderful, tuna was tender and plentiful with fresh from garden tomato assortment. Also enjoyed was the farmers salad with grilled chicken. A high light was the "PBR" fried dill pickles! Friendly chatty servers, for a fun lunch with out of town guests.
A fine dining twist on traditional pub fare. Excellent customer service, delicious tender veal burger, heavily poured cocktails.

Solid place for lunch. I really like the eclectic vibe and the space is quite nice too. I can imagine it being a great place for happy hours. We ordered the poutine, which was very flavorful though I wished it had more chunky beef. The fondue was also nice too (just don't calorie count).

The lobster roll was very fresh, though I wished they had more lobster. I loved how buttery the bun is and it's very lightly toasted and soft and doughy. I feel like that ratio of bun to lobster was just a tad too high, especially if I'm paying $23? Hm... I think maybe I should wait to go to Boston for my next lobster roll. I did, however, like the side salad.

It's also unfortunate that they messed up our table's orders two times, although I guess that's what you get with a lunch crowd.

Aww I am a huge fan of their Duck Poutine, I was told it is the best in Chicago and I believe it certainly! It is even better than in some places in Montreal!!
I just went there to try the Poutine as friends strongly recommended it to me, and I wasn't disappointed. It goes very well with some of their Revolution pale ale. Also, we had a plate of cheese for dessert, which was fine.

We went there on a Thursday evening around 8:30, without any reservation, and managed to sit down at the last available table for 2! Unfortunately, we couldn't get on the patio.

Service was excellent  - always important to emphasize.
The atmosphere of the restaurant is nice as well. Definitely a great place to go, ideally located in from of the AIC.

I haven't had the chance to eat here yet, but I was very impressed with my cocktail experience here yesterday.  My friend from out of town was down in the Loop for a bit, so we decided to meet up for a quick drink.  The Gage was very crowded, but we were able to find a table in the bar area.  Once we sat down, we immediately received water and then our waitress came by.  We may have been a bit underdressed compared to the after-work crowd surrounding us, and we told her we were only staying for a drink, but we still received impeccable service (I am confident that this would not have been the case in many other spots in Chicago, haha.)  She thoroughly answered our questions about the cocktails, going into great detail and explaining the ingredients to us.  When we received our drinks, they were delicious, and the service continued to be excellent until we left.  After this awesome impression, I definitely would like to return for a meal sometime!

Came for an early New Years dinner before ice skating and just because we were not dressed in our fancy gowns we were treated like peasants. Horrible service, didn't even get plates for our appetizers and my friends drink came in a glass with a huge crack in it. We also had to find our waiter various times throughout the meal for assistance. Just because people are not dressed to the 9s doesn't mean they don't have money. This establishment needs to understand that you treat all tables & guests the same. I will definitely not be coming back here. Beyond disappointed.

I've been here twice, once for drinks after work and another for brunch on Sunday. The drink menu has a wide selection and something for everyone. At brunch we got the apple cinnamon french toast and house made corned beef hash. The french toast was easily one of best I've ever had. It's usually always pretty crowded because of the location so we snagged a spot at the bar instead of waiting for a table.

Surprisingly pretty awesome! Fried eggplant sandwich was perhaps the best I have had, and one of our group couldn't be more complimentary of the venison burger.  Great for kids and nice craft beer selection.  Will be a go to place when I am in the Loop!

Located across the street from Millennium Park, the Gage feels like an old-style pub meets steakhouse. Good drinks and good food. The bison tartar was my favorite. The meat itself was lean and blended perfectly with the alioli and cheese. (The server mixed it for us at the table and you could tell he's a pro.) The pork shank was a bit dry, but I really like the cornbread that it came with (but my friend thought it was just ok). Definitely will be coming back!

Flew into town this day, so I was very hungry. This was my first visit to The Gage and we had a great dining experience. Jennifer was our server. She was very good and  efficient. She enhanced our time here.

Our order: Amaretto, Stieglitz Radler, House Poutine, Bison Tartare, and a regular burger. My dinner was the House Poutine. It was so good. Poutine is a Canadian dish. I ate some almost everyday while in Montreal.  Poutine is potato french-fried with meat and gravy served over them.  That is way lacking in detail & the dish deserves a better description. Sorry.

V and I think it was better than the Poutine we ate before. Large serving (more than I could eat).   My Amaretto Sour was right on the money. I add just a slash of OJ when I make it at home. This was almost that good. V said the Bison Tartare was excellent. Hubby loved his Burger.

We would definitely eat here again.

My new discovery this trip was the Stiegl Radler. It is a low alcohol grapefruit beer! It was so refreshing and light!

pics.caption: Poutine! Wonderful and more than I could eat

review.des:
I was excited to eat here since there are many great reviews on Yelp. Hate to say it, but I was a bit underwhelmed. Don't get me wrong, it was pretty good, but nothing to rave about.

I do have to note that the service was excellent, and our waiter was friendly, knowledgeable, and attentive. He helped us veer through the menu and gave us plenty of recommendations. The draft beer list was amazing. We had the pepper appetizer, the scallops, and the venison burger. Everything was good but not omg amazing like I had hoped, especially since the menu is pretty pricey.

Great location though!

Great affordable and sophisticated gastropub with an awesome location: affordable lunches and dinner with fair size portions....I would recommend the caramelized lobster, the creme brûlée, etc. The service is prompt and friendly. The setting is warm and relaxing.

You will probably have to park your park at a private parking around here.

I have been here 3-4 times. I prefer late afternoon in the summer when the doors are open and tables spill onto the sidewalk. Love the roasted peppers and the Tuna tartar with a couple glasses of Prosecco. Very cheery place with helpful, happy staff. Brunch is also a great meal. I love their hash with poached eggs. Yum!

The Scotch egg and the corned beef hash was perfect! The bartender very attentive and helpful with the food. The only thing that went south was the mixed drink. It actually made me vomit and ruined the amazing food I had. I was nauseous for the rest of the day. I was skeptical about the drink, but was willing to try something new. Bummer.

I'll start by saying the food and service were lovely. I got the Scotch Egg to start, followed by the Corn Beef Hash. Both really heavy, really fried, and really delicious. Very hearty midwesterny-type food.

This place gets 2 stars because the server assured my Celiac boyfriend that his dish was gluten-free. Guess what? It wasn't. He got sick immediately.

Gage, please be careful. If you can't guarantee a dish is GF because your kitchen isn't set up that way, that's okay, just say so. We'd have gone somewhere else, no harm done. But don't assure us three times that food is safe when it's not. Someone back in the kitchen obviously didn't take it quite seriously enough or wasn't educated on cross-contamination. Please do something about that before you make someone else seriously ill.

Popular gastropub located right across from Millennium Park which makes for a good spot to swing by to start or end your evening with a meal or a few beers. Full service restaurant available, but I opted to sit at the bar & have a few local draft beers. The bar is long & spacious with a nice wood finish staffed by two bartenders on a laid back Saturday night.

I think the focus of the drink menu is on wine but there's a fair amount of draft beers, local & imported & an excellent whiskey selection.

What really got me interested on the menu here was the house made poutine. Instead of the usual light gravy, the one at Gage uses roasted pork gravy paired with braised pork shoulder, pickled red onions & cheese curds. I think this modern or hipster take on the poutine was every bit as delicious as it sounds & is worth ordering. Deliciousness in every bite.

Chill atmosphere, good alcohol selection, I'd recommend a quick visit.

The Gage used to be phenomenal, standing above most of its competitors but as a gastropub it's lost its shine because it just hasn't kept up with the Chicago scene and customers.

Too much at Gage now shows a heavy where once was more finesse. The signature scotch eggs have overly thick shells, too salty and way over cooked. These should be malleable, rebounding not hard and crusty. The heavy handed mustard just exemplifies what's wrong. It's a total letdown at an exorbitant price.

I should have changed my order because despite asking for my fish to be fried soft and golden- like in the British Isles - the thing came out hard, thickly mattered and fried for so long it was almost Cheetos orange. In contrast the chips were limp and oily. How could these been paired and prepared together is beyond me. Really sloppy and shows either laziness or arrogance in the kitchen. I sent the mess back and reiterated my order. What came out was the reverse- almost burnt fries and barely cooked fish from which you could pour out the oil. I sent that back too and substituted the bison burger which was very well done and paired with perfect fries. Proof positive that they can get it right.

Hate to knock the place but there are too many good places to eat in Chicago to accept this kind of negligence and arrogance in delivering food that any gastrochef would know immediately was well below par.

I won't be back.
Great restaurant. Bring your appetite...pretty hearty (and delicious) stuff. The wine list is awesome and the place is actually good for watching sports.

I have been throughout the world and visited more restaurants than most, but this place really really stands out for their excellent food and customer service - Kudos to Jackie and the entire team - keep up the great work!!

Same owner as Henri. I am a fan of both places. You see the owner walking around really talking to the customers.... you know, not just a drive by to say "how is everything" then moving on. He stops, listens, engages. Billy Lawless cares!

Hubby and I came here after a day at C2E2. I would have talked the Hubs into Henri, but, well, you know what we must have looked like after a day at Comic Book Heaven...

The only complaint I have about The Gage is the noise level. Hubby and I walked in to eat at the bar, but we couldn't hear ourselves talk. We opted for an outside table. After this horrible spring, it was actually nice enough to sit outside! Go figure!

What a pleasant evening. Our waiter was attentive, but not overly so. He let us enjoy our drinks. Mine was a rum based negroni. OMG! Slurp!

We shared fried pickles. Hubs and I have had them many places. They can be too salty; too greasy; too much breading... but these were "just right". Crispy little chips of heaven with a yummy sauce we saved to put on other things that came later.

Hubby had the burger. Looked juicy. I didn't try it, but he looked like he enjoyed it.

I had mussels. They came in a curry sauce. They were very delicious. I also ordered a pate plate. Hmm-mmm... my eyes were bigger than my tummy, so we took it home. I just ate it for lunch. EXCELLENT! It had some sweet jam and vinegar onions to go with it. Yum.

I did have dessert because the butter cake just couldn't be passed up. I am so glad I ordered it. I also took it home and have been savoring it by having two bites a night. It is so moist and buttery that I would go back to The Gage and just order that! I think I may ask Henri to go get me one for dessert next time I eat there!

The only reason I made this 4 stars, not 5 is because of the noise level... but on a nice evening... just go outside!

This place is wonderful. I came here under unprecedented circumstances in early October and left as full as I've never been. In a good way though- I'm pretty consistent when it comes to endless small portions. We started with oysters and fine wine, and worked our way up to elk steak, mashed potatoes and pear goat cheese salad. It was excellent and everything was cooked to perfection- the entire experience was an outdoor patio aphrodisiac.

Best service and very good food.

The service here is top notch. We came here twice and both of our waiters were super friendly and super helpful. They recommended us very good beers and drinks both times.

The food is very good. Most of the items on the menu are a bit pricy but there are some cheaper options as well. We tried both burgers and we loved it! The burgers are very juicy and well prepared. And the best part is it's only $15 and they come with fries. Another good value option is the fish and chips. It's also very good and it's only about $15.

Another thing that you should try here are their cocktails. The old fashioned has the fancy clear square ice and they make it very well.

I like the ambiance but it can get crowded and loud. Also you should make a reservation because there's always a wait.

This swanky restaurant caught my eye while I was walking by Michigan Avenue. I was meeting a colleague for drinks and dinner and I wanted to pick a very Chicago-esque Place for our last night in town. There were a few places that met this description within the area but for some reason, I gravitated toward this one. We got off at a rocky start. I went in, probably not dressed as nicely as I should have been as I did not realize what I would be doing later, and asked for a table for two as my colleague with meeting me there. She stuck me in the back corner right next to the kitchen, as if this was a fun experience. Before she asked me if this was OK, she walked away. Then a man who came over to pour my water asked me if I was OK. I told him I wasn't interested in sitting here and I wanted to be more by the bar, upfront with all of the liveliness. I know beggars can't be choosers because I didn't have a reservation, but I did see a lot of empty tables up front. He said OK, walked away and never came back. Finally someone else came over and told me he could help me. The hostess came back over and resat me where I wanted to be seated. After that experience, I had a bad taste in my mouth, figuratively of course. Once my server came over it calmed me down as she was amazing. Beautiful girl, great service, and totally understood what I meant when I said I'm craving salmon/something light (so girly-I know). She recommended something delicious. When my colleague got there, we ordered martinis, ate, laughed, and it was a great experience. This could be a great place for any occasion. There was a date sitting right next to me and I family on the other side. Only thing is, the seating is very close so a lot like New York. You have to be aware that you might be sitting very close to someone and listening to their every word as they listen to yours. Otherwise, recommend this place for sure.

Fellow yelpers had turned me onto this place so when I noticed it was next door to where we had dinner reservations how could I pass up the opportunity to check it out for pre-dinner/pre-theater DRAANNKSSS! This place is hopin and defiantly a hot spot. We were lucky to swoop in and get seats and the bar and experience their high-end mixology first hand. Although we personally enjoyed their great wine by the glass selection I did quite enjoy watching them do their thang at the bar. They go a step above with the fresh garnishes I saw them peeling for each and every drink. So although I can't speak for the food I would say this is a place to be for high-end cocktails. So come get you drank on. I'll have to come back to experience the food soon!

Visited Chicago for a very short period of time and I saw this place on TV And I wanted to be sure the POUTINE was the real deal.

It was EVERYTHING and more. Delicious, perfectly cooked fries with the gravy, pickled onions and cheese curd I would fly to Chicago again just for these. What a delight!!!

I also tried the burgers, wow. The venison ?? Please order it when u go. Perfectly cooked burger.

We also had a bottle of moscato for the table. We were seated outside and enjoyed the streets of Chicago. Will def be back, great service as well!
Superb dining experience. The service is amazing. The cuisine is unique and really a standout in the city. Romantic and classy.

I think I found my new favorite place.  First of all sat at the bar and the service was great.  Ordered the scallops and some sort of fish wrapped in prosciutto.  Oh lord!!! The scallops were absolutely perfect and the fish was deboned and wrapped.  Their whiskey game is on point! Old fashion probably best around! I woke up the next morning thinking about their food.. Haha. My friend told me their food game is always on point.  Never had a bad meal here.  If your around defiantly recommend stopping in for a bite and drinks!!!

pics.caption: Deboned and wrapped in prosciutto!! Yum

review.des:
We settled here for beers mid-day one day after a morning of walking and sight seeing.  We sat at the bar and had wonderful service from friendly bartenders.

We returned later that evening for dinner.  We ordered the poutine and the fried pickles - both were amazing.  The poutine was everything you dream of in the dish - savory gravy, some finely chopped carrots and onions, chunks of short rib, plenty of cheese curds, and lots of house made fries.  YUM!  The fried pickles were pretty standard but the sauce they bring with them was amazing!

I ordered the duck as my main.  I was quite shocked to find out that they serve the breast of the duck medium rare.  I had no idea you could eat duck any other way than well done!  I was not a fan.  It was exceptionally tough meat and very chewy at that temp.  The leg quarter that was served with it confit was perfect and had amazing flavor.  The risotto and accompanying sauces was also delicious.  

One of our group had the lobster roll and was really pleased with it.  It was a very good sized portion.  Another had the regular burger and loved it.  It was also huge.  The fourth person ordered the fish of the day which was haddock I think.  She was not impressed at all.  She said it had no flavor whatsoever and that the sauce that came with it was the only thing on the plate with flavor.  That was disappointing!

Our waiter for the evening was charming and engaging and the service was impeccable.  I would come here more often if I lived closer!
Amazing food, great service, great ambiance. This is one of Chicago's best places to go out!

Came in late after a 12 hour day. Gamble took care of us completely. From ordering food to picking an amazing bottle of wine, Gamble made the difference for our entire experience.

Do yourself a favor: come here and sit at the bar if Gamble is working. You'll be glad you did.

Sunday night, party of 2, 8p

ok so we ate our faces off.  even the waitress was startled at how much we ordered and how much we ate.  

Excellent service - our server was fantastic.  
Great selection of draft beers and fancy cocktails

*Mussels vindaloo: delicious.  enough flavor to season the mussels but not drown them either. the broth was so good, we drank it like a soup.  hope this is not a faux pas.
*Bison tartar: incredible.  all raw-meat-diseases be damned.  this was awesome.  no raw egg.  fantastic meld of flavors.  
*Baked brie: small pot of baked cheesy goodness that seemed bottomless.  we just kept eating it and there kept being cheese in that pot.  
*Rack of elk $45: neither of us have ever had elk before, so when we saw it, we thought, eh, why not?  my friend loved it and i was so-so about it.  we ordered it with the chimichurri sauce.  i thought it tasted gamey but still edible.  it was cooked perfectly.  i may not be an elk fan.  
*Curry fries: giant ass bowl of fries with a delicious red curry that you dip the fries in.  good but not my fave.  
*Green beans: delicious.  great lemon-orange citrusy essence to them.  cooked well!
*Chocolate toffee cream puffs: not my fave dessert.  the pastry of the cream puffs seemed thick, but the toffee inside was delicious.  chocolate gelato was meh.  

great atmosphere.  it's right on michigan avenue across the street from millennium park.  plenty of seating at tables, booths and the bar.  definitely will be back to try their other menu items.

pics.caption: Rack of ELK, green beans and curry fries

review.des:
Had a special treat last night met my love at the Gage for drinks and dinner.

What an energetic place! Great service, amazing food (House Poutine, Atlantic Black Grouper, and a Porterhouse), and okay priced drinks considering their location on Michigan Ave.

The Gage provided not only the best meal from a recent trip to Chicago, it gave me the best brunch I've had anywhere in quite some time. With impeccable, timely service, gorgeous, luxurious decor, and standard brunch fare with an upscale twist, an early weekend meal at The Gage is a truly lavish experience.

With ample seating room, The Gage is perfect for groups. My party of six was able to be seated immediately upon arrival around 11am on a Sunday after calling less than an hour ahead of time. We started with two orders of fried pickles for the table, which were just what we needed to get our appetites revved up. From there is was on to the main course, and I debated long and hard between the shrimp and grits and the Gage Venison Burger. When our charming waiter longingly described the burger as one of the best in the city, my mind was made up. Cooked a perfect medium rare and topped with smoked gouda, fried jalapenos, woodland mushrooms, pickled onions, and a mustard aioli, my burger exceeded even the loftiest of expectations. It was a messy affair, but one that I savored from the first bite to the last.

My dining companions were equally enthralled with their meals, particularly the corned beef hash (among the best I've ever had, with teeny tiny diced potatoes pan fried for the perfect crunch) and cinnamon raisin brioche french toast, the latter serving as the table's de facto dessert, as it was too large for one person to finish, and sweet enough to cure even the most saccharine of cravings.

Truly a five-star experience all around, and I will be sure to visit again the next time I journey to the Windy City, this time for dinner.
I'm putting one star because this is my favorite place in town. I don't want to have to wait in line to sit down to eat because you got there ahead of me... Don't go PLEASE.

Probably one of my favorite dinner spots in the city. The food is gourmet, satisfying, and predictably excellent.

The decor in here is stellar. It has an upscale,Chicago-style decor. Glossy, dark-green tile is prevalent on the walls with reinforced glass partitions. It's dimly lit by candles and vintage fixtures. I love the feel of this place.

Every time I've taken a date here it's been excellent. Do note: there isn't much in this area other than concert halls or the ballet. The loop is prone to that, but this place sticks out as a destination dinner spot.

The food, goes without saying, is stellar. I've never been disappointed. It is artfully made, in modest portions. THE FISH AND CHIPS ARE THE BEST IN THE CITY (these are upscale f&c, not some typical platter you get at an irish pub). Check out the photos - the creative effort is apparent.

It's moody, with lots of space, great for an impressive dinner with business clients, your date, or even your family. Minus one star for sometimes spotty table service - it can get VERY busy here, so I understand why.

---

P.S. The owner of The Gage is a great, great guy. He was walking around, talking to people, very interested in your experience and how you are doing. He even took the time to help clear tables and assist! Now that's a truly successful business owner - check out The Dawson in the West Loop... an equally impressive and excellent place to get a drink.
Great service, great wine, great food, great atmosphere! What else do you need/ want?

My friend and I had plans to go to Chicago to visit friends before we knew about the Women's March. We had a reservation, so we were able to get in, but the high volume of people in town slowed the service down. However, the food was AMAZING! I was very satisfied and will definitely go back....just not on a weekend there are an extra 100,000 people in the city!

Just worked out at Brick CrossFit...
Had a great brunch here as recovery. The shrimp and grits (sans chorizo) and pumpkin french toast were deelish!! Service was excellent!! Will definitely come back.

Very busy and loud restaurant with a good vibe overall.   I ordered one of the least expensive entrees on the menu - Roasted Amish Chicken. There was nothing wrong with it - or special about it. Presented about half a chicken - mostly deboned- with herbs on top and gnocchi that was mushy.  But $28.00? Really?  It would be worth $16-18 in most restaurants.  So good food, but way over priced.  Two entrees, no sides, no salads, no dessert or coffees, a glass of wine and a beer.  Tab with tip was just under $100.00!  That is overpriced.  I will say that the service was excellent, but The Gage will not become a regular restaurant for us.

Went back for brunch and it was EXCELLENT! I am a big fan of corned beef hash - not the stuff out of a can, but REAL homemade hash - and this was perfect. Served with a delicious hollandaise and perfect poached eggs, I could not have been happier with it. My husband had the benedict with merguez sausage and poblano hollandaise - it was also delicious. We took home a lof of zucchini bread - also fantastic. I wish we loved closer so I could go there every weekend.

Great beer selection, great food, and a perfect location right in the Chicago downtown.

I had the Gage Venison Burger with Smoked Gouda, Fried Jalapeño, Woodland Mushrooms, Pickled Onion, Mustard Aioli.

Beer choices are rotating from select breweries.

Great service, location and environment. I think the lamb is the best, then the fish and then the steak......They are all delicous though. Its just steaks are usually around ~$60 and others are $30-40 and the lamb shank is sensational. The appitizers and sides are mediocore, should've been cheaper.

One of the best meals we've had in awhile.   Great atmosphere, fantastic service and pretty amazing food.  We started with oysters, then enjoyed the farmers salad and moved on to bison tartar and seared scallops.   Our waiter suggested great wine pairings.
Will visit again when in Chicago

If I honestly didn't feel like I stepped into a Business Week magazine rather than a Food Network magazine, I would probably have rated this place a 4.5/5. And should actually be closer to a 4.5 as my experience here was top of the line. Though I did feel that this was a nitch above casual for a lunch outing, the hosts and our waiter certainly didn't make it feel stuffy in there. Service was 5 stars all the way.

My travel buddy and I went to meet with an old friend of mine who happened to move to the city the week before to attend University of Chicago. I'd read great reviews on the food here and it definitely didn't disappoint. The menu was a little small but thankfully, their specials were what wowed us. My friend and I opted for the grilled salmon special while my other friend ordered the shrimp sandwich that came with a side of red quinoa.

Salmon was perfectly grilled, though a little on the salty side, everything else was delish. HOWEVER, the shining dish IMO was the shrimp sandwich. Looking like a fancy bahn mi sandwhich, the bread was perfectly crunched on the outside and fluffy on the inside. The shrimp and all the adds inside the bread was to drool for. Quinoa was also good, though just a little bland.

All in all, had a great time with great company, food, and service. I'd probably suggest a dinner here for those that are locals and work in the area. But as a traveller and for a lunch, I'd check some other places out. This conveniently is located right in front of "The Bean" so I do appreciate a quality restaurant in such a popular, high traffic, location.

4.5/5 stars for dinner & drinks.

Pros -
- Fun, lovely atmosphere
- Beautiful, rustic decor with some great exposed brick & light fixtures
- Amazing cocktails - we tried the G.T.O., Strangers on a Train & an Old Fashioned.  All spectacular and crafted with care by the sweet bartender. $12-14/drink.
- Friendly service from all - hostess, bartenders, server, attendants. My water cup was never empty and that's a big plus in my book!
- Loved the poutine appetizer. We all tried the Scotch Egg for the first time and personally did not love it. I think it may have been overcooked since the egg wasn't runny.  If it is your jam, it's a huge egg and can be shared with 2-3 people.
- We had the steak salad and it hit the spot! Sounds silly about a salad but everything went together perfectly and the steak was cooked just right! My coworker also loved her duck breast entree.
- Lastly, we had the banana bread pudding & subbed in the special ice cream of the night - peanut butter. I could eat that every day!

Cons -
- A little crowded for my taste but we had a great booth so it worked out
- A lot of the bathrooms were out of service

Definitely glad we tried it!

Very nice lunch.  We started with mussels and poutine which were both very good.  Lobster roll was good not great.  Fish and chips were very good.  Service was excellent.  Would definitely recommend if you are in the area.  And despite the fact that the Yelp listing says not good for kids, they were very helpful and patient for our 3 year old.

Found on yelp, this time the reviews lived up to it...

Great locale.

Slick atmosphere.

Quality micro-brews on tap.

Craft cocktails, our waitress (from Romania) provided excellent recommendations.

I had the scallops and they were very tasty.

Would definitely recommend and would do a return visit.

Food: I ordered their southern chicken and biscuit off of their brunch menu. The portion size was pretty decent, not too big, not too small. The more important thing was that it tasted good. They have a small but decent selection of craft beer. The only bad thing I can say is that the craft beers were a bit pricey. They have plenty of other alcohol to choose from if beer is not your thing.

Service: The bartender provided excellent service. He was very quick in taking my orders and attentive to my drinking and dining needs.

Location: This gastropub is conveniently located on Michigan Ave, in the Loop, just across the Cloud Gate. This place is very easy to get to if you're staying in the Loop or taking the train. This might not be the best place to watch a game on TV since they only have two TV's.

Ultra hip and trendy situated in a fabulous location right on Michigan Avenue overlooking the beautiful and very cool Millenium Park. Both times I stopped in (the first, just to look around, and the next night for dinner, it was packed with folks meeting for drinks or having dinner (and was LOUD), but a happy kind of loud.

So many things looked good - the pork porterhouse, roasted rack of elk and whole Idaho rainbow trout, but they seemed a little heavy, and pricey - $30-45. So, I opted for the Gage venison burger, topped w/ smoked Gouda, fried jalapeños, mushrooms, pickled onions and mustard aioli on a super soft bun - it was amazing - every part of it. Even the pickle spear on the side was so much better than the average pickle.

For $4 more, I substituted the fries for the fire roasted mini Shishito peppers, topped w/ cilantro, toasted sesame and dynamite sauce - incredible w/ a tangy kick, and so unique! I could eat these like popcorn every day. Both were very generous portions - definitely enough to share if you're inclined. Tried the Paloma craft cocktail, and it was excellent, too - very fresh and refreshing. Don't let the crowd turn you off, it's worth it!

pics.caption: Shishito peppers w/ cilantro, sesame and dynamite sauce- so unique and delicious!
Cute patio w/ view of Millenium Park, but too chilly tonight

review.des: Great food, nice servers, and perfect location! Highly recommend for people that are going to be hanging out at the Art Institute of Chicago.

Previously really liked this place but hadn't been there in a year and last week it was poor. The scallop salad was three tiny scallops with lettuce, oranges, and no dressing. With all the great food options in Chicago I won't be back.

$120 for lunch for two people including tip and a few drinks but it was seriously delicious. We sat outside and the service was great. We had a special sandwich and a burger and split them. Pricey for lunch but good food and food service.

Best Restaurant of Chicago Loop, Excellent Food and Better Service!
Perfect for different Ages and for Different kinds dates!

We were sure that anything on Michigan Ave that close to the museums and the Bean would be a pricey tourist trap, but The Gage was a very pleasant surprise for us.

On a busy Saturday afternoon, we were seated right away in a spot close to the kitchen. While it was interesting to see the fast-paced routine of the cooks, it did get a little bit noisy sometimes with all the clattering of plates, etc. However, my only other dig at the place was our server; while she was very accommodating, she was a bit snooty at times throughout the meal, and I really didn't appreciate that. Also, another server kept coming around filling up our glasses when we had only taken a few sips; the hovering got a little bit annoying.

That being said, the atmosphere is great, and the food is delicious. We ordered the fried pickles to share and they were such a great light, tart snack - minimal breading, just enough to get the crunch, maximum tartness and crunchiness from the pickle itself; perfect dipping sauce! I ordered a vegetarian soup of the day, with the mushroom sandwich, which I would highly recommend. Shiitakes were perfectly sauteed, and the ratio of greens to mushrooms to aioli to bread was perfect.

A friend and I ate on the patio for a late lunch on Saturday.  Our server was great!  I had the Handcrafted Sausage with potatoes and brie.  The sausage was ok but the potatoes were great.  My friend had the corn and brisket soup and a sandwich with fries.  She raved about the soup but didn't say much about the rest.  

I definitely want to go back.  I wish they had a gf menu.

pics.caption: Handcrafted sausage with potatoes and brie

review.des: Went here for a team dinner good food but the environment is a little noisy! Presentation could be better.

Had a great brunch here with a few friends. It's just steps away from the Millennium Park and Cloud Gate (the Bean). We had reservations, but the place was large enough that it seemed we didn't need them. While there were already lots of people there, we were seated quickly in a large booth. For being a solid brunch/lunch restaurant so near lots of tourist attractions, it was a plus not to have to wait in a long line (unlike places such as the bongo room, yolk, etc)

Everything we ordered was great. We got the special poutine to share, and it was soooo good. My friend got the eggs benedict I believe, which was tasty but also had a side of baked sliced potatoes with brie. Yum!! A nice change from the typical homefries on the side. I got the poached egg on top of the hash, which was also really good. My other friend got the lobster roll, which I didn't try, but she really liked it. If it weren't the morning, I would've gone for the burger, but oh well, everything we ordered was great.

The atmosphere was classy but casual, and our service was also on point. He was attentive and friendly. This place was definitely a pleasant surprise. The prices were also very fair

Wish we could have tried it, but they weren't willing to accommodate us. Yes, we were a party of 14, with kids, but it was 4:30 pm on Saturday and we were looking to have a late lunch and drinks. The restaurant was empty and they claimed they had reservations at 6:00 pm... we promised to give the tables back at 6:00, we offered to have the group split up, and then some, but the manager and hostess were not willing to accommodate us. Frankly, I think it was because we had kids. Not happy!

Went here strictly because it was near the Art Institute (just saw JT's review!).  Large and varied menu, dark wood paneled bar, overall a very nice atmosphere.  I had the lobster roll and it was excellent.  My dining companion was more up for brunch and had an out of this world pumpkin bread french toast.

Definitely will be back to try this place again, would also definitely stop by here for drinks.
Amazing dishes, coupled with great service. I'll be back on future visits to Chicago.

pics.caption: The Egg BLT and Venison Burger in the background. Delicious!!!!

review.des: I had eaten here once before pre-theatre and remembered great food, so when my niece and I found the restaurant at the Art Institute was closed for remodeling, we went across the street to Gage.  Dinner with my intelligent, kind, and interesting niece is special enough for me, but it was made perfect by great cocktail selections, excellent food and wonderful service!!!  I am still smiling, having run to the train in the pouring rain--We loved it and we will be back--thank you:)

I normally love this place. I've been here several times and for the most part, I've never had any complaints. It has the perfect mix of completely casual and upscale. This occasion unfortunately was not nearly what I had come to expect. I made a reservation and told them we would be having a birthday. Upon arriving, we were a little early but they were able to seat us immediately- and in a great, spacious corner booth. The waiter seemed...distracted and just off the entire night. The appetizers we ordered were great but the entrées were just not good. When I made mention of this, he acted like he didn't hear me and said something completely non sequitur. Definitely an off-night for sure. There was a big baseball game on so perhaps that was a factor. Who knows; hopefully it's a one-time occurrence.

This was my second visit to The Gage. Both times I ordered and devoured the venison burger. We made reservations, table was ready when we arrived and service was fabulous. I will return and may even order something different!

Overpriced, snobby service, and food I wouldn't care to eat again (except for those poutine fries... fine if you must come here, get the poutine... those were pretty darn good and the only reason I changed my 2 stars to 3 stars lol...)  

Important stuff:
- Don't get the Elk, unless you're craving for a dried piece of not tasty meat
- Don't get the duck, unless you've never had Chinese style duck before, because once you've had that... this duck meat will taste weird.
- Expect to wait over an hour for your food, because it seems to need to sit in the kitchen for the oil and sauce to harden on your plate first -_-  
- Get the poutine. lol my only one positive thing to say about this place.

My friends and I traveled to Chicago together for the first time and so we decided to have a nice dinner to celebrate our trip. Arrived at Gage, seemed nice and pleasant. Ambiance was nice, felt like we went back in time and were at an old mysterious train station, was kind of cool... dimmed lighting, booth seats, etc.

Checked out Yelp while trying to decide what to order, lots of people said the fish and chips were great, and there were a number of people ordering the burger (I'd say this was probably the least expensive thing on their limited menu of entrees). We asked the server what were some of the popular things to order, and he said the Elk was definitely a must-try (~$50) and he also mentioned that he could'n't understand why people would come here and order their fish and chips (which they were out of) and the burger. But maybe, people order those because they sound safe, and if I were ever made to come back here again, I'd probably rather go with those than any of the other fancy, more expensive dishes on the menu like the duck, elk, and mussels. Anyways, from the start, I found our server to be snobby and condescending, so that was a no no. Second, my sister and I noticed another table with the same number of people, was seated after us, ordered after us (with the same server), got their drinks, basket of bread (which our table never received), and got their food 30 minutes earlier than us. That table actually finished eating and was gone before our table even got our food. Ridiculous.

When our food finally arrived...a hour later, my un-biased opinion about everything:
- Duck poutine; was amazing, super delicious, would recommend everyone getting this
- Mussells; friends said they had had better, would not order again
- Burger; a friend said it was good, but he doesn't have taste buds, so he wouldn't know the difference from in n out and mc donalds. I tried a bite of the burger and it was very much whatever... Why do places even offer things like this on their menu when it's going to taste so not special; better off without this completely.
- Duck entree; the sauce and oil really looked like it had been sitting for awhile (see my photo for reference...so gross), not being biased at all, but this was something that I definitely noticed the moment I got my plate; the duck meat was very soft which was weird to me, and the taste was just ok, nothing special at all and would not recommend this to anyone.
- Elk; this was a major disappointment. We were anticipating this to be really yummy but instead it was a very dried square of meat with nothing else. lol wow.... please don't order this.

And pretty much, this was our experience. Left quite a bad taste and feeling in our mouths... except for those poutine fries. lols.

pics.caption: Duck poutine was the best thing there (would go just for those, and not for anything else!)
The duck... waited over an hour for this and it looked like it had been sitting for awhile (note the oil separating from the sauce)

review.des:
Dropped by for lunch and ordered the salmon tataki. Don't let the small size fool you; at first it looked like one of those items that was all about looks, but there was quite a bit of fish underneath all the decoration as well.
